Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Fundamental Investigation of Micromechanisms of Cyclic Deformation and Fatigue in an Ultrafine Grained Aluminum Alloy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced materials improve the quality of life and significantly impact the sustainability of society. The friction stir processing technique can produce ultrafine-grained aluminum alloys with both higher strength and higher high cycle fatigue life when compared to conventional alloys. However, how the improved mechanical properties emerge from the unique microstructure is not well understood. The microstructure in these new materials consists of grains smaller than one micrometer and a high fraction of stable high-angle grain boundaries. These microstructural features strongly influence the dislocation-based deformation mechanisms. This award supports fundamental research on advanced computational modeling of cyclic deformation mechanisms as well as experimental investigations and characterization to establish microstructure-property relationship for an ultrafine-grained aluminum alloy system. The research will generate knowledge in advancing computational materials engineering for the selected alloy system but will be broadly applicable to similar engineering materials. Results from this research will contribute to the national goal of accelerating the insertion of new materials in the engineering practice. This work will support graduate student research and also help incorporate new understanding of deformation mechanisms into undergraduate courses such as mechanical behavior of materials and advanced materials by microstructural design.

This award supports an integrated computational and experimental approach to systematically study the correlation between cyclic deformation and heterogeneous microstructures of dispersion containing ultrafine-grained alloys. Well-proven concepts of persistent slip bands and extrusion/intrusion in microcrystalline alloys do not apply directly to ultrafine-grained materials because their smaller grain sizes and more high-angle grain boundaries change dislocation micromechanisms of multiplication, recovery and substructure formation. A multi-grain modeling strategy with three-dimensional discrete dislocation dynamics will be used to predict mesoscale dislocation processes and the initiation of slip localization at early stages of cyclic deformation. Specifically, this strategy will use information generated by atomistic simulations to create dislocation-grain boundary models for the discrete dislocation dynamics method. Incorporating dislocation-grain boundary and dislocation-precipitate models, the dislocation dynamics simulations will provide insights into dislocation-based damage accumulation processes in heterogeneous alloy systems. Experimental activities involve performing interrupted mini-fatigue tests and microstructure characterizations using orientation imaging microscopy and transmission electron microscopy to obtain cyclical stress/strain curves, grain size distributions and dislocation arrangements at various stages of high cycle fatigue. These efforts will provide insights into damage accumulation and evolution, help verify computational prediction with early stage data, and build a database of the entire fatigue behavior of the ultrafine-grained alloys.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objectives of the project were:

  • To understand the fundamental dislocation-based micromechanisms during cyclic deformation in ultrafine grained (UFG) alloys with distinctly different stacking fault energy.
  • To experimentally test and characterize the UFG alloys during different stages of the entire fatigue deformation.
  • To understand the role of hierarchical microstructure in delaying the onset of crack nucleation and enhancement of fatigue endurance limit.

 

Major findings from this project include:

  • Two UFG and one fine grain microstructure of 5024 Al alloy were investigated to understand fatigue properties. The S-N (stress-number of cycles to failure) curves revealed that within the UFG regime, smaller grains result in better fatigue properties on the basis of absolute stress levels; while on normalized stress basis, finer microstructure shows improvement in high cycle fatigue region and coarser microstructure in the low cyclic region. Fractography study confirmed that crack initiation and stable crack propagation rate increased with reduction in grain size; while fine grain microstructure had excellent crack propagation properties, making it comparable on normalized stress vs life curve.
  • Excellent tensile strength in a UFG Al0.3CoCrFeNi with two hard phases (YS of 900 MPa, UTS of 1074 MPa and total plastic strain of ~25%) was attributed to the combination of grain boundary strengthening and composite strengthening by hard phases, while the formation of nanotwins led to large ductility. This resulted in a superior fatigue resistance with a fatigue endurance limit to UTS ratio of 0.43 due to the formation of the deformation nanotwins.
  • Fatigue behavior of the Al0.7CoCrFeNi alloy with two heat treatment conditions was studied to evaluate the influence of hierarchical microstructure on the fatigue deformation mechanism. The tensile strength improved from the formation of nano-sized coherent L12 precipitates in the FCC matrix. Fatigue cracks initiate and propagate along the B2/FCC lamellar phase boundary, as do persistent slip bands in the FCC matrix. A zigzag crack-propagating pattern was due to the activation of multiple slip systems. Coherent nano-sized L12 precipitates did not improve fatigue property, as these precipitates are believed to have been sheared during cyclic loading.
  • Excellent strength-ductility combination was achieved by combining hierarchical B2 precipitates with heterogeneous grain structure (hi-HGS) complex concentrated alloy. B2 precipitates of different morphologies have different orientation relationships with the fcc matrix. While the B2 precipitates raise matrix strength, the imposed heterogeneity in grain structure brings out additional long-range back stress with deformation. In addition, the matrix is susceptible to formation of nano-twins during deformation which in turn, increase work-hardening even further. Notably, traditional cold-rolling and subsequent annealing processes, which can be scaled easily for industrial production, were involved in obtaining this hi-HGS CCA. With their vast range of composition and intricate physical metallurgy, complex concentrated alloys provide excellent opportunities to engineer the desired microstructure and create high-performance materials.
  • A unique variant of eutectic high entropy alloy with hierarchical microstructure (EHEAw) was prepared via conventional rolling and heat-treatment of as-cast EHEAc. The cyclic loading properties of both as-cast EHEA and EHEAw were compared in the high cycle fatigue regime. The monotonic load bearing capacity of EHEAw is considerably higher than the same of as-cast EHEA. A unique microstructure consisting of FCC(L12) lamellae, recrystallized FCC grains with high angle grain boundaries and twin boundaries, BCC(B2) precipitates inside FCC matrix, and BCC(B2) lamellae with Cr-rich precipitates was formed. Persistent slip band formation in FCC(L12) lamellae was the main mechanism for crack initiation in EHEAc. Fatigue crack initiation of EHEAw was delayed due to (BCC)B2 precipitates which hinder the path of PSBs.
  • Multi-pass friction stir processing of a dual-phase high entropy alloy resulted in substantial grain refinement and phase redistribution throughout the processed region, thereby significantly increasing its yield strength and ultimate tensile strength. This grain-refined high entropy alloy further demonstrated unconventional fatigue response owing to extreme metastability of the g (FCC) matrix. The pronounced g ? e (HCP) phase transformation within the crack plastic zone enhanced work hardening which reduced crack growth and also promoted crack branching. The simultaneous improvement in fatigue limit and fatigue ratio in comparison with TRIP steels makes this high entropy alloy a strong candidate for cyclic loading applications.
  • Conventional materials exhibit low resistance to crack initiation and propagation rates because of limited energy dissipation during these stages. Ultrafine grained materials show delayed crack initiation but faster propagation rates along grain boundaries under high cycle fatigue regime. However, these trends were overcome in the present work by combining ultrafine grain microstructure with a metastable matrix. A high entropy alloy with minor addition of Cu not only showed delayed crack initiation but also delayed crack propagation in the high cycle fatigue regime. This unconventional fatigue response is attributed to the controlled transformation-induced plasticity effect within the crack plastic zone and effective strain accommodation by the newly-formed e phase by slip and twinning.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The overall objectives of the project were: To understand the fundamental dislocation-based micromechanisms during cyclic deformation in ultrafine grained (UFG) alloys with distinctly different stacking fault energy. To experimentally test and characterize the UFG alloys during different stages of the entire fatigue deformation. To understand the role of hierarchical microstructure in delaying the onset of crack nucleation and enhancement of fatigue endurance limit. Major findings from this project include: Two UFG and one fine grain microstructure of 5024 Al alloy were investigated to understand fatigue properties. The S-N (stress-number of cycles to failure) curves revealed that within the UFG regime, smaller grains result in better fatigue properties on the basis of absolute stress levels; while on normalized stress basis, finer microstructure shows improvement in high cycle fatigue region and coarser microstructure in the low cyclic region. Fractography study confirmed that crack initiation and stable crack propagation rate increased with reduction in grain size; while fine grain microstructure had excellent crack propagation properties, making it comparable on normalized stress vs life curve. Excellent tensile strength in a UFG Al0.3CoCrFeNi with two hard phases (YS of 900 MPa, UTS of 1074 MPa and total plastic strain of ~25%) was attributed to the combination of grain boundary strengthening and composite strengthening by hard phases, while the formation of nanotwins led to large ductility. This resulted in a superior fatigue resistance with a fatigue endurance limit to UTS ratio of 0.43 due to the formation of the deformation nanotwins. Fatigue behavior of the Al0.7CoCrFeNi alloy with two heat treatment conditions was studied to evaluate the influence of hierarchical microstructure on the fatigue deformation mechanism. The tensile strength improved from the formation of nano-sized coherent L12 precipitates in the FCC matrix. Fatigue cracks initiate and propagate along the B2/FCC lamellar phase boundary, as do persistent slip bands in the FCC matrix. A zigzag crack-propagating pattern was due to the activation of multiple slip systems. Coherent nano-sized L12 precipitates did not improve fatigue property, as these precipitates are believed to have been sheared during cyclic loading. Excellent strength-ductility combination was achieved by combining hierarchical B2 precipitates with heterogeneous grain structure (hi-HGS) complex concentrated alloy. B2 precipitates of different morphologies have different orientation relationships with the fcc matrix. While the B2 precipitates raise matrix strength, the imposed heterogeneity in grain structure brings out additional long-range back stress with deformation. In addition, the matrix is susceptible to formation of nano-twins during deformation which in turn, increase work-hardening even further. Notably, traditional cold-rolling and subsequent annealing processes, which can be scaled easily for industrial production, were involved in obtaining this hi-HGS CCA. With their vast range of composition and intricate physical metallurgy, complex concentrated alloys provide excellent opportunities to engineer the desired microstructure and create high-performance materials. A unique variant of eutectic high entropy alloy with hierarchical microstructure (EHEAw) was prepared via conventional rolling and heat-treatment of as-cast EHEAc. The cyclic loading properties of both as-cast EHEA and EHEAw were compared in the high cycle fatigue regime. The monotonic load bearing capacity of EHEAw is considerably higher than the same of as-cast EHEA. A unique microstructure consisting of FCC(L12) lamellae, recrystallized FCC grains with high angle grain boundaries and twin boundaries, BCC(B2) precipitates inside FCC matrix, and BCC(B2) lamellae with Cr-rich precipitates was formed. Persistent slip band formation in FCC(L12) lamellae was the main mechanism for crack initiation in EHEAc. Fatigue crack initiation of EHEAw was delayed due to (BCC)B2 precipitates which hinder the path of PSBs. Multi-pass friction stir processing of a dual-phase high entropy alloy resulted in substantial grain refinement and phase redistribution throughout the processed region, thereby significantly increasing its yield strength and ultimate tensile strength. This grain-refined high entropy alloy further demonstrated unconventional fatigue response owing to extreme metastability of the g (FCC) matrix. The pronounced g ? e (HCP) phase transformation within the crack plastic zone enhanced work hardening which reduced crack growth and also promoted crack branching. The simultaneous improvement in fatigue limit and fatigue ratio in comparison with TRIP steels makes this high entropy alloy a strong candidate for cyclic loading applications. Conventional materials exhibit low resistance to crack initiation and propagation rates because of limited energy dissipation during these stages. Ultrafine grained materials show delayed crack initiation but faster propagation rates along grain boundaries under high cycle fatigue regime. However, these trends were overcome in the present work by combining ultrafine grain microstructure with a metastable matrix. A high entropy alloy with minor addition of Cu not only showed delayed crack initiation but also delayed crack propagation in the high cycle fatigue regime. This unconventional fatigue response is attributed to the controlled transformation-induced plasticity effect within the crack plastic zone and effective strain accommodation by the newly-formed e phase by slip and twinning.
